description.narrative: Legal Resources Foundation har ansökt om 35 000 000 SEK som kärnstöd till Access to Justice Programme. Insatsmålen är följande: 1) Ökad tillgång till rättsskipning för marginaliserade och utsatta genom tillhandahållande av juridisk hjälp. 2) Att stärka marginaliserade och utsatta personers förmåga att hävda sina rättigheter genom tillhandahållande av information samt genom att utbilda samhällsadvokater och juridiska rådgivare som kan öka medvetenheten i lokala samhällen. 3) Bidra till en möjliggörande miljö där demokratiska rättigheter hävdas av en informerad allmänhet som kräver skydd och efterlevnad av konstitutionella och mänskliga rättigheter. 4) Ett effektivt och ansvarsfullt leveranssystem 5) Ökad tillgång till och förståelse för juridisk information.

The Legal Resources Foundation has applied for SEK 35 000 000, which is core support towards its Access to Justice Programme. The interventions objectives are as follows: 1) Increasing access to justice for the marginalized and vulnerable through the provision of legal assistance. 2) Strengthening the capacity of the marginalized and vulnerable to assert their rights through the provision of information as well as training community paralegals and peer legal advisors who can raise awareness in communities. 3) Contributing to an enabling environment where democratic rights are claimed by an informed public that demands the protection and enforcement of constitutional and human rights. 4) An efficient and accountable justice delivery system 5) Increased access to and understanding legal information.

description.narrative:
4,423 Community volunteers successfully played the multiplier role reaching 27 953 people (9530M 18423F). They shared legal information (Inheritance, Wills, Domestic Violence, Sexual offences amongst others) and referred cases to various critical service providers which include but not limited to, LRF offices, the Department of Social Development, Births and Deaths Registrar and the Courts.
The LRF assisted 21,017(15,549F; 5,468M) people through its various legal services interventions. 6,069 (3,643F;2426M) benefitted through LRF in-offices services; 4,470 (2,887F;1,583M) through mobile legal aid clinics; 8,754 ( 5,715F;3,039M) through help desks; 1,287(729F;558M) through call center; 437 (149F;288M) through prison visits. 215 of these were children.
The LRF conducted research on recognition of paralegals and access to justice in Zimbabwe. The research findings provided a solid platform for discussions around the formal recognition of paralegals at the conference that was held in March 2020. The research findings are being used by the Ministry of Justice and other key stakeholders to make informed decisions on the best way to proceed in terms of formal recognition of paralegals.
The LRF strategic litigation/public interest pillar contributed significantly to law and policy reform through the outcome obtained in the case LRF and Deaf Zimbabwe Trust Vs Ministry of Justice. The two organisations challenged the constitutionality of section 193 of the CP&E Act which violated the constitutionally enshrined rights of the deaf and mute including the recognition of sign language as one of the official languages of Zimbabwe (Section 6, Constitution). The matter was successfully finalized in that the High Court declared Section 193 of the CP&E Act unconstitutional to the extent that it violated the rights of accused persons. The case yielded a milestone achievement for a total population of over 300 000 deaf people in Zimbabwe.
LRF produced a Gender and Human rights manual for traditional leaders in Zimbabwe. LRF has so far conducted training of Chiefs in 5 provinces in Zimbabwe. The manual has been well received with varying patterns being established in as far as issues to do with gender are approached in different cultures. Chiefs from Matebeleland have proved to be very progressive and accommodative towards gender issues. This is also reflected in the fact that 2 women hold the office of Chief in Matebeleland North and all the courts have women serving in various capacities such as secretaries and assessors.
